author: @spiraljumper74
text:
I spent a lot of my childhood in a very poor, pretty-much all black area of Nola, I was like the one white kid on the block. Eric Adams reminds me of every black conservative politician that would come around every two years shopping for votes. They‚Äôd have big smiles, and they‚Äôd be saying brother, sister, elder. They‚Äôd be saying it so much it rang obviously false, everybody knew it. And then you‚Äôd see them on TV at a fundraiser, talking to a white audience with the code switched and the policies of ‚Äúlaw and order‚Äù front and center. 

Eric Adams so desperately wants to convince his fellow black people that he‚Äôs on their side, when he‚Äôs obviously in the bag for capital and white supremacist forces. It‚Äôs nakedly just political doublespeak, and he‚Äôs not even good at it. Even Charlemagne didn‚Äôt buy and that guy was uncritically parroting the GOP line on immigration the entire time.

Hi Olay!

I saw the original podcast, and I already knew how some outlets would treat your presence. You are an intelligent, and confident person. We know how much that is a threat to others that only viewed you as an "angry black woman", "rude", or "woke", which are he only thing they can say when they don't like that you didn't mince words with what you were saying.
